Alex,

MixMaster only does single-phase equilibrium.  You need to account  
also for solid carbon formation.  Take a look at some of the Cantera  
Python demos to see how to do this.

Dave


On Jul 15, 2007, at 3:54 PM, alex.bruccoleri wrote:

> I am currently trying to figure out the hydrocarbon species of
> dissociated methane at roughly 2,000 K and 50 atm. Using MixMaster
> with Python, GRI-Mech 3.0, 1 mole of CH4 gets well divided into
> Hydrogen, Acetylene and a variety of other gaseous hydrocarbons.
> What is peculiar is that two other thermo chemical calculators I have
> used, Gaseq and the NASA CEA calculator, predict a large concentration
> of solid carbon and gaseous hydrogen. Furthermore an experiment was
> done to dissociate Methane to produce carbon and hydrogen at 1 atm at
> similar temperatures. The link is below and MixMaster used the way I
> did yields different results. Does anybody have experience with using
> Cantera to predict dissociation of Methane?
>
> Thanks,
>
> Alex
>
> http://www1.eere.energy.gov/hydrogenandfuelcells/pdfs/28890h.pdf
>
